title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Bastrop County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Bastrop County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

title: Policy Compliance Records - Wallingford Public Schools

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Policy Compliance Records - Wallingford Public Schools
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act (C.G.S. § 1-200 et seq.), I respectfully request access to the following public records:

PRIMARY RECORDS REQUESTED:
- All policies and procedures regarding employee conduct during custody disputes or family court matters
- Documentation of FERPA compliance training for staff, including attendance records and training materials
- Records showing how complaints to the Superintendent's office are processed, tracked, and resolved from January 1, 2024 to present
- Any legal consultations, advice, or opinions received regarding employee conflicts of interest from January 1, 2024 to present

COMPREHENSIVE DISCLOSURE REQUIREMENTS:
This request includes, but is not limited to:
- All responsive records regardless of format (paper, electronic, audio, video, social media, messaging apps)
- Records stored on personal devices if used for official business
- Records in possession of contractors, consultants, or third parties acting on behalf of the agency
- Draft documents, notes, calendars, and informal communications
- Records that have been deleted but remain recoverable
- Metadata and audit logs associated with electronic records

SEARCH REQUIREMENTS:
- Search all relevant custodians, not just those specifically named
- Search all email accounts, shared drives, and backup systems
- Include records of employees no longer with the agency
- Search alternative spellings, nicknames, and partial names

PRODUCTION STANDARDS:
- Provide records in native electronic format when possible
- Do not convert searchable documents to non-searchable formats
- Preserve all metadata including timestamps and sender/recipient information
- Provide a privilege log for any claimed exemptions

If any responsive records have been destroyed, please provide:
- Documentation of the destruction
- Reason for destruction
- Date of destruction
- Authority for destruction

If you claim any exemption under the Freedom of Information Act, please:
- Identify the specific statutory exemption
- Explain how the exemption applies to each document
- Provide redacted copies where partial disclosure is possible
- Consider whether public interest outweighs any claimed exemption

This request seeks records that serve the public interest in government transparency and accountability. Please construe all exemptions narrowly and err on the side of disclosure.

Please preserve all potentially responsive records immediately upon receipt of this request to prevent spoliation.

As these records serve significant public interest, please waive all fees. If fees cannot be waived, please provide detailed cost estimate before proceeding.

Thank you for your assistance.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

john Conrad

title: Food service Inspections for Class IV licenses Danbury, CT

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Food service Inspecions for Class IV licenses Danbury, CT
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am in receipt of your departments FOI request for Food Service License Renewals for 2025-2026. I find it very concerning that several Class IV Establishments have yet to be renewed over 6 months after prior permit expired. One of  which is a daycare that services a vulnerable population. 
Public Health Code Regulations have an inspection interval requirement.

Please furnish copies of DPH required inspections for the following Establishments for calendar years 2024, 2025, and 2026 until the receipt of this request.

FSE-22-151	5/14/2025 18:34	Active	Sushi Do Danbury Hospital	                        Class IV
FSE-22-5	6/11/2025 14:37	Active	Cedar Gables Preschool & Childcare	Class IV
FSE-23-33	6/19/2025 22:51	Active	Bambu	                                                                Class IV

Please provide explanation if no inspections have been conducted.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kevin Paige

Good Afternoon:

This will acknowledge receipt of your Freedom of Information request,
received in this office on January 22, 2026.


Please be advised that the City of Danbury is firmly committed to providing
prompt access to all records subject to disclosure under Connecticut
General Statutes §1-210, et. seq.  Accordingly, all documents will be
assembled and reviewed as quickly as reasonably possible in light of other
responsibilities and immediate commitments.  Although the City of Danbury
takes your request seriously and will respond as promptly as possible, we
reserve the right to petition the Freedom of Information Commission for a
declaratory ruling regarding requests that may be exempt from disclosure.


Please note, that there will be a charge of $.50 per page, and any amount

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me.

title: DHS-OIG Working Papers OIG-22-47

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DHS-OIG Working Papers OIG-22-47
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Description of Records Sought (pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.3b)
All working papers, interview notes, correspondence, and other agency records DHS-OIG created, received, or maintained in preparing the June 30, 2022, report to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Acting Director Tae Johnson regarding the Folkston ICE Processing Center and Folkston Annex in Georgia, operated by The GEO Group, Inc. A copy of that report is available here: https://www.oig.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/assets/2022-07/OIG-22-47-July22.pdf. 

Likely Custodians: 
The following DHS-OIG Custodians are believed to have responsive documents and should be tasked: 
James Cuffari, Ph.D., John D. Shiffer, Chief Inspector; Stephanie Christian, Supervisory Lead Inspector Ian Stumpf, Senior Inspector; Erika Algeo, Inspector; Brett Cheney, Inspector; Lisa Knight, Communications Analyst; Lorraine Eide, Independent Referencer.

Proposed Temporal Period: 
The following time period should be searched: 
October 1, 2021 - Present (i.e., the date on which DHS-OIG FOIA tasks an adequate search for responsive records). 
We are willing to negotiate a narrower temporal period upon a representation from DHS-OIG that responsive records are unlikely to exist in all or part of the temporal scope we have requested. 

Likely Systems of Records: 
DHS-OIG should query any email systems the Likely Custodians use, as well as the government-issued phones these custodians use. 
DHS-OIG should query any SharePoint or similar drive containing records regarding the Folkston Inspection conducted in November 2021. 
DHS-OIG should query the JICMS for any responsive records as described above. 

Expedited Processing Request (pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)
On behalf of the Al Otro Lado #DetentionKills Transparency Initiative, we respectfully request expedited processing. 

Expedited processing is warranted under 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)(1)(i) - Harm to individuals from delayed production. DHS-OIG concluded in its publicly available report.  

“Folkston did not meet standards for facility conditions, medical care, grievances, segregation, staff-detainee communications, and handling of detainee property. We identified violations that compromised the health, safety, and rights of detainees. Folkston facilities were unsanitary and dilapidated, with torn mattresses, water leaks and standing water, mold growth and water damage, rundown showers, mold and debris in the ventilation system, insect infestations, lack of access to hot showers, inoperable toilets, an inoperable thermometer display on a kitchen freezer, and an absence of hot meals. Facility medical staff did not provide timely access to specialty care or adequate mental health care for detainees. Folkston did not provide timely or complete responses to detainee grievances and requests. Folkston also did not consistently provide required services to detainees in segregation and inappropriately handcuffed detainees. Further, ICE did not consistently respond to detainee requests in a timely manner and did not provide detainees with paper grievance forms and submission boxes as required. ICE also did not provide detainees sufficient contact with deportation officers. Lastly, the facility has improperly handled detainee property. In addition, Folkston has not met staffing levels required by the contract with ICE to ensure proper detainee oversight. In addressing COVID-19, Folkston did not consistently enforce use of masks and social distancing. In April 2021, Folkston began providing COVID-19 vaccinations to detainees.”

On May 25, 2022, ICE responded to OIG’s 13 recommendations, purportedly providing “corroboration” that Folkston had been brought into compliance. ICE followed up on June 13, 2022, seeking OIG close its recommendations. OIG treated 12 of 13 recommendations as satisfied and closed them. However, it is unclear how or why OIG concluded it could rely upon the representations of ICE regarding how it had addressed each recommendation, such that the people locked inside Folkston experience a material change in their daily conditions. In several instances, ICE disputed OIG’s findings, even while indicating it would “concur” with the recommendations that it make changes to implement standards compliance. (See pages 39-42 of Report No. 22-47.

Expedited processing is warranted under 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)(1)(iii) — Loss of Substantial Due Process Rights to people inside Folkston from delayed production.

Even after ICE represented to DHS-OIG that it had corrected many the violations it admits OIG documented during the unannounced inspection, detained people inside Folkston reported to DHS many of the very same violations OIG described. According to multiple detained individuals, these conditions unabated.
See, e.g., https://www.albanyherald.com/news/protests-at-ice-detention-center-mount-as-expansion-plans-move-forward/article_6c8cf39c-c25c-11ec-be63-8bbf37990359.html. 

An active hunger strike remains ongoing at Folkston to protest these conditions. 

In the past, ICE officials have attempted to deny the very conditions OIG found in its unannounced inspections during the agency’s communications with House Appropriations Homeland Chair Lucille Roybal-Allard, according to FOIA records obtained from ICE: https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/6705734-ICE-Emails-Pertaining-to-Congressional-Inquiries.html. 

Expedited processing is warranted under 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)(1)(iv) — A matter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government's integrity which affect public confidence.

The future of ICE detention in Georgia and ICE’s use of private immigration detention contractors like The GEO Group is a matter of widespread and exceptional media interest on  which there exist possible questions about the government’s integrity which affect public confidence, and these records requests are directly responsive to this media interest. Accordingly, Expedited Processing is warranted under Section 5.5(e)(1)(iv). 

President Joe Biden told organizers at a Georgia car rally who interrupted his event to demand he keep his promise to close private prisons and immigration detention centers, “Give me Five Days, Man.” https://www.newsweek.com/joe-biden-says-give-me-five-days-hecklers-calling-closure-detention-centers-1587639. As the video makes clear, the President of the United States was referring to privately operated immigration detention centers, as well as private prisons. See also: https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/biden-georgia-rally-speech-protest-b1839959.html; https://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2021/04/30/biden_to_protesters_give_me_another_five_days_to_fix_immigration.html; https://nypost.com/2021/04/29/biden-heckled-by-abolish-ice-protesters-teases-action-in-5-days/. 

Instead of ending private prisons in Georgia May 2021, President Biden ordered the termination of ICE’s contract with the Irwin County Detention Center. By December 2021, however, it became clear that far from fulfilling his stated promise, the Biden Administration would actually expand its use of private immigration detention in Georgia: https://www.advancingjustice-atlanta.org/news/closefolkston. https://creativeloafing.com/content-500557-news-brief-private-prison-undergoing-expansion-while-under. 

Then, in February 2022, the Atlanta Journal Constitution reported exclusively that the Biden Administration planned an unprecedented expansion of Folkston that would make it the largest ICE facility east of the Mississippi. https://www.ajc.com/news/exclusive-south-georgia-immigration-detention-complex-aims-to-expand/QN5G2BFOPREQHEBDOPPAX2PSVI/. 

In apparent violation of the Homeland Security Acquisition Regulations and Federal Acquisition regulations, this historic expansion would occur through a no-bid, single-vendor contract expansion. The beneficiary: The GEO Group. People supporting those locked inside Folkston protested: https://www.splcenter.org/presscenter/splc-planned-expansion-private-ice-detention-center-georgia-betrayal-biden. 

A people’s movement seeking depopulation of the Folkston facility by ICE and cancellation of the Folkston Contract has been active since 2022. http://www.charltoncountyherald.com/news/second-rally-held-at-the-folkston-ice-processing-center/article_7254cb22-bfe3-11ec-8548-978ce9320949.html.  

The timing of DHS-OIG and ICE’s responses to the findings of the November 2021 unannounced inspection raise significant questions about the Biden-Harris Administration’s planned expansion of Folkston. At the exact time OIG was informing ICE Folkston was serially non-compliant (OIG No. 22-47 contains perhaps more documented violations of ICE standards than any other DHS-OIG inspection of an ICE facility in history), ICE was planning to reward the contract with an additional expansion. At the exact same time OIG was informing ICE that its contractors had failed to follow through on the financial penalties against GEO that would have followed from the 2019 and 2020 contract discrepancy reports ICE issued, ICE was planning to further reward the non compliant contractor with a no-bid, multi year, multimillion dollar expansion. 

Why did OIG wait and negotiate with ICE, given the violations it documented, rather than issuing a Management Alert, as it did in Torrance, NM? 

What “corroboration” did ICE provide OIG? 

Why, given the serial failures of ICE to accurately document the violations OIG found on unannounced inspection, did OIG take ICE at its word and not conduct a second unannounced inspection before closing out its recommendations? 

Why do people inside Folkston still report the same violations OIG documented if OIG has concluded ICE remedied the violations? 

The records requested carry the potential to answer these questions and more. The answers are required now — BEFORE ICE signs a multimillion dollar expansion of a facility that less than 8 months ago failed an unannounced inspection. Failure to grant expedited processing will deprive the public, people inside and those working with Congress and the agency of the public records necessary to corroborate or disprove the current allegations that Folkston is not fit for human occupancy, and is incapable of reform. 

Finally, it appears that despite knowing of OIG’s findings, executives from The GEO Group made affirmative statements during shareholder calls and in public SEC filings that are contradicted by ICE’s concurrence with those findings. Because GEO’s market capitalization of $1.9bn is based nearly exclusively on its ability to obtain and maintain contracts with government partners — including the ~25-35% of its revenue ICE payments represent — the investing public has an urgent need to know whether GEO’s executives misled shareholders and the SEC regarding the services the company renders at Folkston, and its relationship with ICE as a contracting partner. 

I certify that the above statements are true and correct pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e)(3). 

Requestor: 
Al Otro Lado and its #DetentionKills Transparency Initiative

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: DHS-OIG Working Papers OIG-22-47 (Case No: 2022-IGFO-00222)
communications.communication:
Mr. Free,

We apologize for the delay. We anticipate responding to your request around March 15, 2023.  Please note this is only an estimate and the actual time required to respond to your request (which may be later or sooner than the aforementioned date) depends on the number, types, and complexity of responsive records located during our records search.  Unfortunately, we cannot predict exactly when the processing of your request will be completed as we currently have a large backlog of requests; however, we are using our best efforts to process all requests with due diligence.  We appreciate your patience as we continue with processing your request.

Sincerely,

DHS-OIG-FOIA Team

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Hall County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Hall County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

title: Dataset: 911 Call Data (City Of Reno Public Safety Dispatch, Reno, Nv, Usa)

communications.subject: RE: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Dataset: 911 Call Data (City Of Reno Public Safety Dispatch, Reno, Nv, Usa)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

RAW Computer Aided Dispatch Data queried out of your emergency phone system on 911 calls for service from January 2014 to the most recent date data is collected. In CSV, TXT, or XML format, a machine-readable spreadsheet (not XLSX format). 

Here are the column headers which I am requesting:

Master Incident Number or Event Number – Unique numerical identifier of the call for service
Case Number – If an incident report was written, this is the file number, which can be joined to the incidents and arrests datasets
Call Date – Date the call for service was generated
Call Time – Time the call for service was generated
Source – How the call was generated from the public, or self-initiated by an officer
Priority – The priority level of the call response, with ‘P’ being the highest, followed in order numerically
Nature – The description of the call for service.
Address – The block number and street or intersection of the call for service.
Latitude/longitude - coordinates for call of service
X – Mapping coordinate of the call for service
Y – Mapping coordinate of the call for service
District – The patrol district where the call for service was located.
Beat – The patrol beat where the call for service was located, which is a sub-division of the district
Tract – The census tract where the incident occurred, based on 2010 census data
Disposition – How the call for service was closed
Cancelled – Whether the call for service was cancelled prior to officer arrival
Dispatch Date and Time - The exact date and time when the dispatcher sent the call to emergency responders, such as police, fire, or EMS
Entry Date and Time - The date and time when the call was initially logged into the 911 computer-aided dispatch (CAD) system
Received Date and Time - The date and time when the 911 call was first answered by the dispatch center
Enroute Date and Time - The date and time when the assigned responder (e.g., a patrol car, ambulance, or fire truck) began traveling to the incident location
On Scene Date and Time - The date and time when the responder arrived at the scene of the incident
Close Date and Time - The date and time when the incident or call was marked as completed or resolved in the CAD system
Dispatcher ID - A unique identifier for the dispatcher who handled and managed the 911 call. This may be used for tracking or auditing purposes

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Filed Requests

communications.subject: RE: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Dataset: 911 Call Data (City Of Reno Public Safety Dispatch, Reno, Nv, Usa)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Upon review, additional data fields are necessary to fully interpret the records already requested and/or produced. I therefore request the following additional column headers, to the extent they exist in your CAD system, for the same date range (January 2014 to the most recent date data is collected), in CSV, TXT, or XML format:

* Unique Identifier – A unique numerical identifier for each call for service, if distinct from the master incident or event number
* Dispatcher ID(s) – Identifier(s) for all dispatchers who handled the call, if multiple
* Responder ID – A unique identifier for the responding unit(s) or team(s)
* Prime Unit – Identifier indicating the primary response unit
* Other Units – All additional responding unit identifiers
* Back-up Requested – Indicator or code showing whether back-up was requested
* Transport – Indicator (Y/N) of whether transport occurred
* Transport Start and End Times – If transport occurred
* Transport Destination Address – The address or facility to which transport occurred
* Program or Response Type – Any field identifying non-police, co-response, or alternative response teams (including behavioral health, crisis, or care-based units), if applicable

If any of the above fields are stored under different names, codes, or tables, I request the functional equivalent fields.

I also request any available data dictionary or codebook necessary to interpret these fields.

If you deny any portion of this supplemental request, please cite the specific statutory exemption relied upon and provide the applicable appeal procedures as required by law.

As before, these records are requested for non-commercial purposes and will be made available to the general public. Please inform me in advance of any fees associated with fulfilling this request.

Thank you for your cooperation.

Sincerely,
FR

communications.subject: General Public Records :: G015831-011926
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

 
Dear Filed , 
The result of your public records request is available on the City of Reno Public Records Center. Please click on the link below to access your records: General Public Records - G015831-011926  *Please note that portions of your request have been redacted for the following reasons: 
Dispatch Logs retained to the minimum period of two (2) calendar years from the date of the dispatch (NRS 11.190 (4)(e), NRS 707.500, NRS 239B.030) 
Dispatch does not obtain/retain all the data requested all available data have been released. 
This shall serve to close out your request. If you have any additional questions, please feel free to contact the City Clerk's Office Public Records Division at 775-348-3932. 
PLEASE NOTE: The Nevada Revised Statutes does not require a governmental body to create new information, to do legal research, or to answer questions about the records you receive. 

Thank you for contacting the City of Reno. 
Sincerely, 
Records Division 
City Clerk's Office Please note any confidential, proprietary, or protected information will be redacted prior to the release of the records. There could be a charge for copies of public records. If the estimated cost of the copies requested is $25.00 or more, the requester will be required to pay in full prior to reproduction. Materials will be held for 14 days. If not retrieved, the requester will be charged in full for a second reproduction in addition to any unpaid original charges. Advance payment will be forfeited if material is not retrieved.

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

9/1/24 near 2125 S ESPINA ST, Dona Ana, NM, 
1/9/25 near 2306 S ESPINA ST D11, Dona Ana, NM 
4/10/25 near E UNIVERSITY AVE/LOCUST, Dona Ana, NM,

and 9/5/2025 near EPDC ANNEX, Dona Ana, NM
by the Las Cruces Police Department (LCPD), NMSU Police, and DASO.

I am specifically requesting:

The complete incident and arrest reports, including officer narratives and any probable cause affidavits

Any body-worn camera (BWC) footage from responding officers

Any 911 call audio and transcripts

CAD logs, dispatch records, or radio traffic related to the incident

RE: Reference # P005183-113025 Dear Beyonce Salvador, The City of Las Cruces received the following public records request from you on December 01, 2025: To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

I am requesting all records related to the arrests of Elijah Ray Chavez on 
9/1/24 near 2125 S ESPINA ST, Dona Ana, NM, 
1/9/25 near 2306 S ESPINA ST D11, Dona Ana, NM 
4/10/25 near E UNIVERSITY AVE/LOCUST, Dona Ana, NM, 
7/9/25 near 1410 S SOLANO, Dona Ana, NM, 
8/9/25 near 2306 S ESPINA #11, Dona Ana, NM 
and 9/5/2025 near EPDC ANNEX, Dona Ana, NM 
by the Las Cruces Police Department (LCPD), NMSU Police, and DASO. 

I am specifically requesting: 

The complete incident and arrest reports, including officer narratives and any probable cause affidavits 

Any body-worn camera (BWC) footage from responding officers 

Any 911 call audio and transcripts 

CAD logs, dispatch records, or radio traffic related to the incident 

Any photographs, witness statements, or scene documentation 

This request is made in the public interest to promote transparency in domestic incident responses and the handling of battery cases involving household members. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Beyonce Salvador 

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2143405/ 
The purpose of this message is to provide you with a notification relating to the Inspection of Public Records Act (hereinafter “IPRA”) request you provided the City of Las Cruces (hereinafter “City” or “Las Cruces”). Under NMSA 1978, § 14-2-8, the City has determined that it does not have possession of and/or responsibility for the 911 call audio and transcripts, CAD logs, radio traffic, or any other dispatch records that you have requested.  However, the City knows the proper custodian of these records to be Mesilla Valley Regional Dispatch Authority (MVRDA), 911 Lake Tahoe Ct., Las Cruces, NM, 88007, (575) 526-0795, https://www.mvrda.org/records-request-instructions/.  As such, on December 1, 2025, the City forwarded your request to MVRDA.  To expedite your request, you may consider submitting an additional records request to that agency's records custodian directly.  In light of this notification, the City considers the request for dispatch records closed.  New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) 1978, § 14-2-8(C) states, in pertinent part, that a “written request . . .shall identify the records sought with reasonable particularity.” The purpose of this requirement is to provide governmental agencies with the information necessary to accurately and fully respond to public record requests. Upon review, the City has determined that your request, as currently written, is too broad to process effectively. In order to facilitate a thorough and accurate response, the City will separate each case referenced in your request into individual requests. This approach allows us to address each case independently and ensures a more efficient and complete response. 

Accordingly, this request is now closed. Please refer to the respective requests for each case moving forward. Sincerely, 
Christine Rivera 
Records Custodian 
(575) 541-2112

communications.subject: [Records Center] Police Records Request :: P005228-120125
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: Police Records Request, Reference # P005228-120125 Dear Beyonce Salvador, The City of Las Cruces received the following public records request from you on December 01, 2025: Original Request P005183-113025 

I am requesting all records related to the arrests of Elijah Ray Chavez on 
7/9/25 near 1410 S SOLANO, Dona Ana, NM, 

I am specifically requesting: 

The complete incident and arrest reports, including officer narratives and any probable cause affidavits 

Any body-worn camera (BWC) footage from responding officers 

Any 911 call audio and transcripts 

CAD logs, dispatch records, or radio traffic related to the incident 

Any photographs, witness statements, or scene documentation 

This request is made in the public interest to promote transparency in domestic incident responses and the handling of battery cases involving household members. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Beyonce Salvador 
The purpose of this message is to provide you with a partial response to the Inspection of Public Records Act (hereinafter “IPRA”) request you provided the City of Las Cruces (hereinafter “City” or “Las Cruces”). The City has gathered, reviewed, and appropriately redacted the following public records associated with your request: 

Nine (9) documents 
 
  *  New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) Section 14-2-1.1 states “Protected personal identifier information contained in public records may be redacted by a public body before inspection or copying of a record.” The term “protected personal identifier information” is defined within NMSA Section 14-2-6(F) to include:  (1) all but the last four digits of a: (a) taxpayer identification number;  (b) financial account number; (c) credit or debit card number; or (d) driver’s license number;  (2) all but the year of a person’s date of birth; (3) a social security number; and (4) with regard to a nonelected employee of a public body in the context of the person’s employment, the employee’s nonbusiness home street address, but not the city, state or zip code;  therefore, any of the above-described “protected personal identifier information” found within the responsive records have been redacted. New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) Section 14-2-1(N) states “[e]very person has a right to inspect public records except as otherwise provided by law.” NMSA Section 31-26-4(A) states that “A victim shall have the right to be treated with fairness and respect for the victim's dignity and privacy throughout the criminal justice process.” The term “Victim” is defined within NMSA 31-26-3(F) to mean “an individual against whom a criminal offense is committed. "Victim" also means a family member or a victim's representative when the individual against whom a criminal offense was committed is a minor, is incompetent or is a homicide victim. The term “criminal offense” is defined within NMSA 31-26-3(F) to include twenty-one (21) specific crimes. Therefore, any personal information associated within Victim(s) as defined by the Victim’s Rights Act have been redacted. A download link with the contents of this request has been e-mailed to you from AXON.  This download link expires in three (3) days. Please contact our office by replying to this email or via telephone if you have any issues accessing the documents or if you wish to receive the documents in another format. Pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 14-2-10, the City has determined that your written request is excessively burdensome and/or broad. More specifically, the City has determined that it requires an additional reasonable period of time to gather, review, and appropriately redact any and all public records associated with your request.  Although the City cannot anticipate when the remainder of the responsive records associated with your request will become available, the City will produce them within a reasonable period of time. Due to a high volume of requests, the City will be providing rolling disclosures associated with this request. Further, the City will provide a written status update regarding your request within thirty (30) days. While the City may be able to process a portion of your request before that time, we are not guaranteeing this result. We appreciate your patience and understanding in this matter. 

Christine Rivera, Records Custodian, is the official responsible for any redactions and/or denial of your request. Thank you for your attention to this matter. Should you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact my office. Sincerely, 
Christine Rivera 
Records Custodian 
(575) 541-2112

The purpose of this message is to provide status update regarding the Inspection of Public Records Act (hereinafter “IPRA”) request you provided the City of Las Cruces (hereinafter “City” or “Las Cruces”). Pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 14-2-10, the City has determined that your written request is excessively burdensome and/or broad. More specifically, the City has determined that it requires an additional reasonable period of time to gather, review, and appropriately redact any and all public records associated with your request. 

The City is still currently in the process of gathering, reviewing, and appropriately redacting the public records associated with your request. Due to a high volume of requests, the City will be providing rolling disclosures associated with this request. As such, you can expect action regarding this request within thirty (30) days. While the City may be able to process a portion of your request before that time, we are not guaranteeing this result. We appreciate your patience and understanding in this matter. 

Should you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact my office. Sincerely, 
Christine Rivera

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: Police Records Request, Reference # P005228-120125 Dear Beyonce Salvador, The City of Las Cruces received the following public records request from you on December 01, 2025: Original Request P005183-113025 

I am requesting all records related to the arrests of Elijah Ray Chavez on 
7/9/25 near 1410 S SOLANO, Dona Ana, NM, 

I am specifically requesting: 

The complete incident and arrest reports, including officer narratives and any probable cause affidavits 

Any body-worn camera (BWC) footage from responding officers 

Any 911 call audio and transcripts 

CAD logs, dispatch records, or radio traffic related to the incident 

Any photographs, witness statements, or scene documentation 

This request is made in the public interest to promote transparency in domestic incident responses and the handling of battery cases involving household members. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Beyonce Salvador 
The purpose of this message is to provide you with a partial response to the Inspection of Public Records Act (hereinafter “IPRA”) request you provided the City of Las Cruces (hereinafter “City” or “Las Cruces”). The City has gathered, reviewed, and appropriately redacted the following public records associated with your request: 

Two (2) videos 
 
  *  New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) Section 14-2-1.1 states “Protected personal identifier information contained in public records may be redacted by a public body before inspection or copying of a record.” The term “protected personal identifier information” is defined within NMSA Section 14-2-6(F) to include:  (1) all but the last four digits of a: (a) taxpayer identification number;  (b) financial account number; (c) credit or debit card number; or (d) driver’s license number;  (2) all but the year of a person’s date of birth; (3) a social security number; and (4) with regard to a nonelected employee of a public body in the context of the person’s employment, the employee’s nonbusiness home street address, but not the city, state or zip code;  therefore, any of the above-described “protected personal identifier information” found within the responsive records have been redacted. New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) Section 14-2-1(N) states “[e]very person has a right to inspect public records except as otherwise provided by law.” NMSA Section 31-26-4(A) states that “A victim shall have the right to be treated with fairness and respect for the victim's dignity and privacy throughout the criminal justice process.” The term “Victim” is defined within NMSA 31-26-3(F) to mean “an individual against whom a criminal offense is committed. "Victim" also means a family member or a victim's representative when the individual against whom a criminal offense was committed is a minor, is incompetent or is a homicide victim. The term “criminal offense” is defined within NMSA 31-26-3(F) to include twenty-one (21) specific crimes. Therefore, any personal information associated within Victim(s) as defined by the Victim’s Rights Act have been redacted. A download link with the contents of this request has been e-mailed to you from AXON.  This download link expires in three (3) days. Please contact our office by replying to this email or via telephone if you have any issues accessing the documents. Pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 14-2-10, the City has determined that your written request is excessively burdensome and/or broad. More specifically, the City has determined that it requires an additional reasonable period of time to gather, review, and appropriately redact any and all public records associated with your request. Due to a high volume of requests, the City will be providing rolling disclosures associated with this request. As such, you can expect action regarding this request within thirty-five (35) days. While the City may be able to process a portion of your request before that time, we are not guaranteeing this result. We appreciate your patience and understanding in this matter. 

Christine Rivera, Records Custodian, is the official responsible for any redactions and/or denial of your request. Thank you for your attention to this matter. Sincerely, 
Christine Rivera 
Records Custodian 
(575) 541-2112

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Bedford County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Bedford County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Samuel Sinyangwe.

title: Florida DOT Removal of Street Art

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Florida DOT Removal of Street Art
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

The Department of Transportation issued to a statement to CNN, which reported (at https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/22/us/pulse-orlando-removal-rainbow-crosswalk-hnk):

“Last week, local governments not in compliance for local roads began receiving notifications to bring their roadways up to state standards to ensure locals govern themselves accordingly,” the department told CNN in a statement. “In addition to ensuring all local governments comply, FDOT completed a review of all state-maintained roadways and is now correcting pavement markings not in compliance. That includes street art previously installed on state right of way, such as the intersection of Orange Avenue in question.”

I request a copy of all the "notifications to bring their roadways up to state standards" with respect to "pavement markings" or "street art" as referenced by the Department's statement.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

You are seeking any and all documentation and correspondence received by or transmitted to the Hawaii County Public Works Department regarding the “Makea Stream Bridge” located in Pepeekeo, Hi. title: Flipper Zero Documents/Emails (Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department)

communications.subject: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: Flipper Zero Documents/Emails (Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Emails and documents containing the term "Flipper Zero" or "FlipperZero"

Specifically:
1) All emails that contain the term "Flipper Zero" in the body or subject line (please include attachments) [Timeframe: January 2022 through present]
2) All email attachments that contain the term "Flipper Zero" in the name or body (if you are able to conduct attachment searches) [Timeframe: January 2022 through present]
3) All files in shared drives containing the term "Flipper Zero" in the name or body of the document. [Timeframe: Documents from January 2020 through present]

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Alan J. Segal

communications.subject: Public records request
communications.communication:
Good morning,

I am an attorney in the County Counsel's office assigned to advise the District Attorneys Office on civil matters.  We have received your public records act request.  Of note, the attachment states a date of October 30, but it was sent to us via Muckrock on November 19.

The request as stated is overbroad and unduly burdensome.  A search of all District Attorney email communications for the words "prostitution," "sex trafficking" and "human trafficking" for an 11 year period would result in an unreasonably large volume of communication on every case touching upon these issues, as well as every training or discussion on these topics across a large office.  Much of that material would be exempt from disclosure under the CPRA, but working through each document to determine which were not exempt would take years, and is impracticable.

I would like to help identify the specific documents that are of use to you, so that we can make a targeted search.  Let me know if it would help to discuss over the phone.

[cid:image001.png@01DC5AC5.61298380]
Hilary Kerrigan | Deputy County Counsel
Office of the County Counsel, County of Santa Clara
70 West Hedding, East Wing, 9th Floor | San José, CA 95110
Office: (408) 299-5925  Mobile: (626) 319-0136
Hilary.Kerrigan@cco.sccgov.org<mailto:Hilary.Kerrigan@cco.sccgov.org> | counsel.sccgov.org<https://counsel.sccgov.org/>
Pronouns: she/her/hers

NOTICE TO RECIPIENT: The information in this email is confidential and may be protected by the attorney-client and/or work product privileges. If you received this email in error, any review, use, dissemination, distribution, or copying of it is strictly prohibited.  Please notify Administration, Office of the County Counsel, of the error immediately at 408-299-5900 and delete this communication and any attached documents from your system.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: California Public Records Act Request: PPR SCC DA 10.2025
communications.communication:
Hello Ms. Doogan,

Thank you for speaking to me on the phone just now.  I understand that your main interest is in learning about the specific cases prosecuted in our County related to the topics you identified.  As I mentioned over the phone, we do not release protected personal identifying information under the California Constitution, nor do we release protected criminal history information or identities of victims under the Penal Code.  If you are interested in deidentified or aggregate data, please let me know the details and I can determine whether such data exists, or alternatively whether it can be extracted via computer programming for a fee.  You can also review the District Attorney's data dashboard here:  Santa Clara County DA Dashboard<https://data.dacalifornia.org/santa-clara>
The DA's website has reports, data, and policies on various topics here:  Publications and policies | Office of the District Attorney | County of Santa Clara<https://da.santaclaracounty.gov/publications/publications-and-policies>

As I explained to you, we do not have a method to run a key word search for documents across the District Attorney's Office generally and I will need you to describe what you are looking for before I am able to search for and identify potentially responsive public records.  You were unable to articulate a focused request over the phone, though I spent many minutes describing to you the various categories of available records, and attempting to redirect you from your insistence on a broad keyword search.  To the degree a keyword search is your primary objective, you can search the County ordinance code here: Code of Ordinances | Santa Clara County, CA | Municode Library<https://library.municode.com/ca/santa_clara_county/codes/code_of_ordinances>, you can review the Board of Supervisors policy manual here:  Board of Supervisors Policy Manual | Office of the Clerk of the Board of Supervisors | County of Santa Clara<https://cob.santaclaracounty.gov/governing-documents/board-supervisors-policy-manual>, and you can search meetings, agendas, and related materials for the Board of Supervisors here:  Board of Supervisors Policy Manual | Office of the Clerk of the Board of Supervisors | County of Santa Clara<https://cob.santaclaracounty.gov/governing-documents/board-supervisors-policy-manual>  The search term "human trafficking" on the last of these resources garnered 3,501 results when I searched just now, so there should be ample material for your preliminary review there.

Please reach out if you formulate a more focused request upon review the above.  In the meantime, we consider this request to be closed.

[cid:image001.png@01DC5AFB.3E5B6360]
Hilary Kerrigan | Deputy County Counsel
Office of the County Counsel, County of Santa Clara
70 West Hedding, East Wing, 9th Floor | San José, CA 95110
Office: (408) 299-5925  Mobile: (626) 319-0136
Hilary.Kerrigan@cco.sccgov.org<mailto:Hilary.Kerrigan@cco.sccgov.org> | counsel.sccgov.org<https://counsel.sccgov.org/>
Pronouns: she/her/hers

I understand that the office of the District Attorney of Santa Clara has no way to search for words like prostitution, sex trafficking and human trafficking but you did have responsive documents when searching the emails. I expect that you can provide those.
As far as the links you’ve provided below, they  do not contact contact signed actual contracts, reports including financial, MOUs or communications with words prostitution, sex trafficking and human trafficking by the District Attorney of Santa Clara County.
Maxine Doogan

title: restricted access school library

communications.subject: Tennessee Public Records Act Request: restricted access school library
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Tennessee Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Public reports show that this school district has been subject to curricula and book challenges: 

https://www.williamsonscene.com/news/wcs-board-removes-three-books-restricts-access-for-two-in-school-libraries/article_a7305bc6-b74e-11ef-af14-03bf747b756b.html

Therefore, I request the following: 

1) All instructional materials, presentations and presentation materials (including recorded video and audio, PowerPoint files, prepared remarks, and slides formats), and other guidance related to “tennessee book ban law”, “state law implementation”, “restricts access”, “sexually explicit”, “policy revision”, “porn”, or “materials policy”. This includes A) any notes taken during meetings that discuss book bans B) any other document that has been used to help explain book bans, including internal documentation, public relations materials, and executive summaries.

2) Any digital communications (including but not limited to emails and text messages) as well as documents, (including but not limited to PDF, word processing, excel, and slide documents) about, pertaining to, or mentioning “the perks of being a wallflower”, “where the crawdads sing”, “walk two moons”, “curriculum removed”, “extremely loud & incredibly close”, or “speak”.

3) Any emails, presentations, videos, memos, recordings, or other records mentioning “tennessee book ban law”, “state law implementation”, “restricts access”, “sexually explicit”, “policy revision”, “porn”, or “materials policy”.

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Geauga County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Geauga County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Ohio Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

communications.subject: West Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Budget (South Charleston Police)
communications.communication:
Good morning,

Attached please find the City of South Charleston’s adopted budget document for Fiscal Year 2024–2025, as prepared and submitted in accordance with the requirements of the West Virginia State Auditor’s Office. This document represents the official, itemized budget format required by the State Auditor and reflects how departmental appropriations, including the Police Department’s budget, are presented and approved.

In addition, I have attached the Police Department’s internal line-item expenditure budget proposal for the fiscal year, which details the approved expenditure categories comprising the Police Department’s total budgeted amount.

Please note that the City does not further break down or internally itemize revenue sources beyond what is presented in the West Virginia State Auditor–approved budget document.

To the extent you are seeking underlying accounting records or expenditure detail beyond the adopted and approved budget documents (i.e., transactional or accounting-level support), those records are available for in-person inspection in accordance with the West Virginia Freedom of Information Act. Please contact our office to arrange a time during normal business hours should you wish to review additional records.
Sincerely,

Kris Taylor, CPA, CICA
Assistant City Treasurer
City of South Charleston
(304) 720-5985

title: Five Below – Final Enforcement and Compliance Records (2025)

communications.subject: Michigan Freedom of Information Act Request: Five Below – Final Enforcement and Compliance Records (2025)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records sufficient to document the existence, status, and outcomes of regulatory inspections, compliance determinations, and enforcement actions involving Five Below, Inc. locations in Michigan during calendar year 2025, as administered by the Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (MDARD).

This request is limited to pricing-related inspections and compliance activity conducted under the Shopping Reform and Modernization Act and related pricing statutes.

Specifically, I request records sufficient to show:

The total number of pricing inspections conducted at Five Below locations in Michigan during calendar year 2025.

The number of inspections resulting in “Not In Compliance” determinations.

The number of inspections resulting in “In Compliance” determinations.

Records sufficient to indicate whether any enforcement action, settlement, assurance of discontinuance/compliance, or other formal resolution was finalized or executed in connection with these inspections.

Records sufficient to show the dates on which final compliance determinations or closures were issued.

This request seeks summary-level, outcome-level, or final administrative records only and does not seek underlying investigative workpapers or materials exempt from disclosure.

I am not requesting:

Personally identifying information of complainants or witnesses.

Ongoing or open investigative materials.

Attorney-client privileged communications.

Internal deliberative or pre-decisional documents.

Drafts or internal legal strategy materials.

If any portion of this request is denied, please identify the specific statutory exemption relied upon and release all reasonably segregable, non-exempt portions.

I request responsive records in electronic format where available.

This request is made for informational and public oversight purposes and is not for commercial use.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Public Records Request Desk

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: First Amendment Trainings for Federal Law-Enforcement Officers (Immigration and Customs Enforcement)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any materials or programming (including handouts, slideshows, videos, textbooks, or other media) used in connection with providing training or guidance to law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the following subjects: (a) The First Amendment; (b) protests or demonstrations; (c) freedom of speech or expression; (d) filming police officers. This request is limited to materials used in trainings since January 1, 2020.

2. Any policy concerning whether trainings on the topics mentioned in (1) are mandatory, or regulating the frequency of such trainings.

3. A copy of any document sufficient to show the most recent training conducted for law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the subjects in (1). For example, this could be a receipt or contract for an outside vendor or speaker, or it could be a dated sign-in sheet from the training.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-56528
communications.communication:
08/27/2025 

Adam  Steinbaugh 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR191862 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-56528 
 
Dear Requester: 

This acknowledges receipt of your 8/25/2025, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), for records pertaining to: 1. Any materials or programming (including handouts, slideshows, videos, textbooks, or other media) used in connection with providing training or guidance to law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the following subjects: (a) The First Amendment; (b) protests or demonstrations; (c) freedom of speech or expression; (d) filming police officers. This request is limited to materials used in trainings since January 1, 2020; 
2. Any policy concerning whether trainings on the topics mentioned in (1) are mandatory, or regulating the frequency of such trainings; and 
3. A copy of any document sufficient to show the most recent training conducted for law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the subjects in.  Your request was received in this office on 8/25/2025. 

Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you’re able to narrow the scope of your request please contact our office. Narrowing the scope may speed up the search process. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner. 

Provisions of the FOIA allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS Interim FOIA regulations as they apply to non-commercial requesters.  As a non-commercial requester, you will be charged 10 cents per page for duplication; the first 100 pages are free, as are the first two hours of search time, after which you will pay the per quarter-hour rate ($4.00 for clerical personnel, $7.00 for professional personnel, $10.25 for managerial personnel) of the searcher.  We will construe the submission of your request as an agreement to pay up to $25.00. You will be contacted before any further fees are accrued. 

We have queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 

If you have any questions, please contact FOIA Public Liaison, Daniel Edgington at 500 12th Street, SW, Washington DC 20536 or (866) 633-1182. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Your request has been assigned reference number 2025-ICFO-56528. Please use this number in future correspondence. 

Sincerely, 

ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-56528
communications.communication:
Adam  Steinbaugh 
N/A 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR191862 
263 Huntington Ave 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-56528 

Dear Requester: 

This letter is the final response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 8/25/2025.  You have requested records pertaining to: 1. Any materials or programming (including handouts, slideshows, videos, textbooks, or other media) used in connection with providing training or guidance to law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the following subjects: (a) The First Amendment; (b) protests or demonstrations; (c) freedom of speech or expression; (d) filming police officers. This request is limited to materials used in trainings since January 1, 2020; 
2. Any policy concerning whether trainings on the topics mentioned in (1) are mandatory, or regulating the frequency of such trainings; and 
3. A copy of any document sufficient to show the most recent training conducted for law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the subjects in. ICE has considered your request under the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. § 552. 

ICE considered the foreseeable harm standard when reviewing the record set and has applied the FOIA exemptions as required by the statute and the Attorney General’s Guidance. 

A search of the ICE Office of Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO) for records responsive to your request produced 5 pages that are responsive to your request.  After review of those documents, I have determined portions of 5 pages will be withheld pursuant to Exemptions of the FOIA as described below. 

ICE has applied FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7(C) to protect from disclosure the names, e-mail addresses, and phone numbers of DHS employees, as well as other third-party information contained within the documents. 

FOIA Exemption 6 exempts from disclosure personnel or medical files and similar files the release of which would cause a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.  This requires a balancing of the public’s right to disclosure against the individual’s right to privacy.  The privacy interests of the individuals in the records you have requested outweigh any minimal public interest in disclosure of the information.  Any private interest you may have in that information does not factor into the aforementioned balancing test. 

FOIA Exemption 7(C) protects records or information compiled for law enforcement purposes that could reasonably be expected to constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.  This exemption takes particular note of the strong interests of individuals, whether they are suspects, witnesses, or investigators, in not being unwarrantably associated with alleged criminal activity.  That interest extends to persons who are not only the subjects of the investigation, but those who may have their privacy invaded by having their identities and information about them revealed in connection with an investigation.  Based upon the traditional recognition of strong privacy interest in law enforcement records, categorical withholding of information that identifies third parties in law enforcement records is ordinarily appropriate.  As such, I have determined that the privacy interest in the identities of individuals in the records you have requested clearly outweigh any minimal public interest in disclosure of the information.  Please note that any private interest you may have in that information does not factor into this determination. 

ICE has applied FOIA Exemption 7(E) to protect from disclosure internal agency case numbers and internal agency URLs contained within the document. 

FOIA Exemption 7(E) protects records compiled for law enforcement purposes, the release of which would disclose techniques and/or procedures for law enforcement investigations or prosecutions, or would disclose guidelines for law enforcement investigations or prosecutions if such disclosure could reasonably be expected to risk circumvention of the law.  I have determined that disclosure of certain law enforcement sensitive information contained within the responsive records could reasonably be expected to risk circumvention of the law.  Additionally, the techniques and procedures at issue are not well known to the public. 

You have a right to appeal the above withholding determination.  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of this letter, within 90 days of the date of this letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.8. You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

Provisions of FOIA allow DHS to charge for processing fees, up to $25, unless you seek a waiver of fees.  In this instance, because the cost is below the $25 minimum, there is no charge. 

If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St., SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009.  Additionally, you have a right to right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Sincerely, 

Megan Davis 
Deputy FOIA Officer, Operations 

Enclosure(s):	5 Pages 
Note: If you are receiving this message by email and responsive records are not included as an attachment to the email, please log in to your SecureRelease portal account to view the responsive records.
