communications.subject: [Records Center] City Public Records Request :: W070085-050825
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of May 08, 2025, Reference # W070085-050825. 

Dear Daniel Moore, 

My name is Michael Manning and I am the City of Worcester's (City) new Records Access Officer. Part of my transition into this role has been to review outstanding requests and attempt to bring them to a resolution. It has come to my attention that your May 8, 2025 public records request to the City remains outstanding. This request sought the following: Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law (M.G.L. c.66, §10), I respectfully request access to all records, documents, and communications related to the hiring process for the Microsoft 365 Administrator position within the Department of Innovation & Technology, City of Worcester, posted in 2025.As 

This request includes, but is not limited to: 

1. **All interview materials**, including: 
- Interview scoresheets, panelist rankings, written or digital evaluations 
- Any compiled assessments, rubrics, candidate comparison summaries, or recommendation memos 

2. **All internal communications** related to the hiring process, including: 
- Emails, memos, letters, Microsoft Teams or Slack messages, and calendar invites 
- Meeting recordings, scheduling threads, and attachments 
- Communications sent or received by Michael Hamel, Samantha Sendrowski, **Moby George**, HR personnel, interview panelists, or any Department of Innovation & Technology leadership 
- Specifically covering any candidates, test results, decision timelines, or escalation concerns 
- From April 1, 2025 to the present date 

3. **Hiring process documentation**, such as: 
- Full timeline of job posting, interview scheduling, test administration, debriefs, and offer stages 
- Number of applicants, screening procedures, and filtering criteria 
- Any instructions or documentation provided to interviewers 

4. **All assessment materials**, including: 
- Technical test prompts, evaluation rubrics, scoring forms 
- Written/recorded test feedback and related correspondence or commentary 
- Internal discussions on the test’s creation, intent, or purpose 

5. **All offer documentation**, including: 
- Drafts and final offer letters (candidate names may be redacted) 
- Related internal approvals, HR communications, or final decision emails 

6. **Meeting materials**, including: 
- Agendas, minutes, summaries, attendance logs, and calendar invites from hiring-related meetings 

7. **Any records referencing candidate follow-up, escalation, reconsideration, or delays**, including: 
- Emails or notes discussing communication from candidates 
- Internal messages referencing escalation to the CIO or Department leadership 
- Records discussing hiring delays, decision deferrals, or process suspension 

8. **Documentation of any changes to the role or reporting structure**, including: 
- Revisions to the job description, responsibilities, or departmental ownership of the Microsoft 365 Administrator role 
- Especially any such documentation involving Samantha Sendrowski or **Moby George** 

Please include **all responsive documents from April 1, 2025 through the present**, including any drafts, tracked changes, metadata, or attachments. I request these records be provided **electronically** in original formats (.pdf, .msg, .docx, .eml, etc.), with metadata preserved where applicable. 
initial matter your request for "all records, documents, and communications related to the hiring process for the Microsoft 365 Administrator position within the Department of Innovation & Technology, City of Worcester, posted in 2025." fails to reasonably describe the record or category of records that you are seeking. The Suffolk Superior Court found that under the Public Records Law “[t]he reasonable description requirement contemplates that a requesting party will identify documents or categories of documents with sufficient particularity that government employees will be able to understand exactly what they are looking for, and then make a prompt production.” See Jaideep Chawla v. Dept of Revenue, Suffolk. Sup. No. l 784CV02087, at 2 (January 23, 2019). The court further indicated “[r]equests for documents that are articulated with very broad language that calls upon non-lawyer administrative personnel to interpret the scope of what is sought, and then make fine judgments about what documents are and are not sufficiently ‘related’ to the category of materials requested, will not satisfy this statutory standard.”  Accordingly, your request for a virtually unlimited scope of documents "...related to the hiring process for the Microsoft 365 Administrator position within the Department of Innovation & Technology, City of Worcester, posted in 2025" is not sufficiently particular as to satisfy the statutory standard of a request that “reasonably described the public record sought.” See G. L. c. 66, § 10(a)(i). 
I will now proceed to address the enumerated categories of your request. With regards to the items sought by categories one (all interview materials) and four (all assessment materials) these requests seek records that are exempt under Exemption (L) of the Public Records Law. These records constitute questions and answers, scoring keys and sheets and other materials used to develop, administer or score job interviews for the Microsoft 365 Administrator and similar positions within the City's government. The City frequently reuses identical or very similar questions when conducting job interviews. To release these records would risk future candidates gaining an unfair advantage when interviewing with the City.  The City will also withhold "[a]ny instructions or documentation provided to interviewers" and "screening procedures, and filtering criteria" under Exemption (L) for the reasons noted above. 
With regards to the portions of your requests that seek communications from the City and between City employees, pursuant to G. L. c. 66, § 10(b)(vii), it is valid for the City to suggest a “reasonable modification of the scope of the request or offer to assist the requestor to modify the scope of the request if doing so would enable the City to produce records sought more efficiently and affordably.” See G. L. c. 66, § 10(b)(vii). In order for the City to search for communications responsive to your request, I would suggest that you provide key words for the communications that you are searching for and specific city employees or departments who you believe may have records responsive to your request (I understand that for some of the items sought that you provided names of City employees) but it would be helpful to expand this for all communications sought.  In addition to the aforementioned suggestions, it may also be useful to narrow the date range of your request. 
With regards to your request for "[a]ll offer documentation" (category 5), the City will withhold all offer letters under Exemption (c), offer letters are found within City employees personnel files and are therefore exempt from disclosure. See Colman M. Herman v. City of Boston, et. al., Suffolk Superior Court, Civil Action No. 2384CV2395 (June 20, 2024) (“personnel files . . . shall be considered exempt under exemption (c)") 
Finally in light of the time elapsed since you placed your public records request, should you wish to withdraw this request, please let me know and the City can consider this request closed. 
Under the Public Records Law, I must inform you that you have the right to appeal this response to the Supervisor of Records pursuant to subsection (a) of section 10A of the Public Records Law and 950 CMR 32.08(1). You also have the right to seek judicial review of an unfavorable decision by commencing a civil action in the superior court under subsection (c) of section 10A. 
Sincerely, 
Michael Manning 
Records Access Officer 
City of Worcester Law Department

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Recruitment and Hiring (Dallas Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting records related to the department's efforts to recruit and hire new officers:
Records include digital and physical, released in their native forms (Excel, PDF, etc)

- ad purchases
- contracts with vendors for ad placement, recruitment and hiring 
- market research and data, if collected
- brand and department strategies created by ad agencies or internally
- data related to applications, KPIs of recruitment and hiring campaigns
- PowerPoint or equivalent presentations, including accompanying documents related to recruitment, hiring, and marketing strategies
- Budgets for recruitment and hiring internally, and the total money spent 
- Pay bonuses or financial incentives to retain officers
- Data by year on the number of officers, sworn and non-sworn

Search from 2021 to today's date.
Please provide in rolling production

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

title: Library Contract Request: Lexis Nexis (Nexis Uni) (Arizona State University)

communications.subject: Arizona Public Records Law Request: Library Contract Request: Lexis Nexis (Nexis Uni) (Arizona State University)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arizona Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

The most recent contract, governing, base, or master license agreement with Lexis Nexis relating to the licensing of library database Nexis Uni; and

All related terms and conditions, terms of service, amendments, addenda, appendices, attachments, product terms, MOUs, MOAs, data processing agreements, and/or letters of intent; and

All financial documents or records of financial transactions, exchanges or obligations with language governing the use of library database Nexis Uni. 

Responsive materials include all contracts, agreements, amendments, appendices, invoices, and any other documents listed above that incorporate language governing terms of use of library database Nexis Uni.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

mo

communications.subject: Your Arizona State University public records request #25-211 has been submitted.
communications.communication:
Arizona State University ************************************************************************ Your record request #25-211 has been submitted successfully. Thank you for submitting a public records request to Arizona State University. We will begin reviewing your request now. If we need additional information to process it, or if we are unable to do so, we will be in touch with you shortly.  Otherwise, we will begin gathering any responsive records from the relevant departments and/or individuals at ASU. After the records have been gathered and individually reviewed to determine if they are responsive and whether any confidential information needs to be withheld or redacted, they will be provided to you. The amount of time necessary to complete this process varies depending on a variety of factors, including how extensive the request is, how responsive information is stored, and what kinds of review and redaction are necessary.  Please be aware that ASU receives a large number of records requests and we may be occupied in processing requests received prior to yours. You are welcome to check on the status of your request at any time through the online portal you used to submit your request (https://asu.nextrequest.com/). When the responsive documents are ready for you, you may also use this portal to access them and to pay any charges associated with your request. If you have additional questions regarding this process or the status of your request, you may submit them through the portal or by email to publicrecords@asu.edu.  ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact Arizona State University.

Change your email settings | Visit our help center

title: Flock Contracts and Emails

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Flock Contracts and Emails
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. All past and active contracts, NDAs, MOAs, MOUs, invoices, and other agreements with Flock Safety.
2. All emails received by Columbia County Sheriff's Office employees from the @flocksafety.com domain since January 1, 2025. Please include attachments and associated metadata.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse
